content: The commission is established to promote a national dialogue on bioethics. The Commission to Promote a National Dialogue on Bioethics is established within the Institute of Medicine with 25 members appointed by various leaders. The Commission to Promote a National Dialogue on Bioethics, established within the Institute of Medicine, requires members to be appointed by leaders of the Senate and House of Representatives, representative of various fields, excluding members of Congress or political appointees. Appointments must be made by December 1, 1998. The Commission shall meet at the call of its Chairperson or a majority of its members, with a quorum consisting of 13 members. Vacancies shall be filled within 30 days, and members shall receive no additional compensation for their service. The Commission members receive travel expenses and per diem. The Commission's duties include providing a forum for public discourse on bioethical issues and submitting reports to Congress. The chairperson can appoint staff without regard to civil service laws. The chairperson can appoint staff without regard to civil service laws. The Commission shall be appointed and paid without following certain provisions of the United States Code. Experts and consultants can be hired with approval, and suitable office space will be provided by the General Services Administration. The Commission may hold public hearings and request federal agency personnel for assistance without interrupting their civil service status. Federal agencies must provide technical assistance to the Commission as needed. The Commission may use the United States mails and obtain information from Federal agencies to carry out its duties. Administrative support services can be requested as needed. The Commission can request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis. For printing and binding costs, the Commission is considered a committee of Congress. The Commission will establish 6 subcommittees, including those focusing on legal, theological, philosophical, ethical, medical, and scientific issues. The Commission will establish 6 subcommittees, including those focusing on legal, theological, philosophical, ethical, medical, scientific, social, and private sector issues. Each subcommittee will have specific membership criteria. The Commission will establish 6 subcommittees with specific membership criteria, including individuals from the private sector and experts in relevant fields. Meetings of the subcommittees will be approved by the Commission. The Commission will prepare and submit a report to Congress by December 31, 1999, and annually thereafter. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Commission.
